title: Proverbs Chapter 16 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Proverbs chapter 16 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Proverbs Chapter 16 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Proverbs Chapter 16.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:1, where do the preparations of the heart and the answer of the tongue come from?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:1 states that the preparations of the heart in man and the answer of the tongue is from the LORD.

questions.question: What does the LORD weigh according to Proverbs 16:2?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:2 states that although all ways of a man are clean in his own eyes, the LORD weighs the spirits.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:3, what should be committed to the LORD to have thoughts established?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:3 instructs to commit thy works unto the LORD to have thy thoughts established.

questions.question: Who has made all things for himself, including the wicked for the day of evil?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:4 declares that the LORD has made all things for himself, even the wicked for the day of evil.

questions.question: What kind of person is an abomination to the LORD according to Proverbs 16:5?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:5 says that everyone that is proud in heart is an abomination to the LORD.

questions.question: What purges iniquity according to Proverbs 16:6?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:6 explains that by mercy and truth iniquity is purged.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:7, what happens when a man's ways please the LORD?
options: He makes even his enemies be at peace with him
questions.correctAnswer: He makes even his enemies be at peace with him
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:7 states that when a man's ways please the LORD, he makes even his enemies be at peace with him.

questions.question: What is better than great revenues without right according to Proverbs 16:8?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:8 says better is a little with righteousness than great revenues without right.

questions.question: Who directs a man's steps as said in Proverbs 16:9?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:9 shows that a man's heart deviseth his way, but the LORD directs his steps.

questions.question: What is in the lips of the king as stated in Proverbs 16:10?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:10 says a divine sentence is in the lips of the king.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 16:18 teaches that pride goes before destruction and a haughty spirit before a fall.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:18 clearly states that pride goes before destruction and a haughty spirit before a fall.

questions.question: True or False: According to Proverbs 16:32, he that is slow to anger is worse than the mighty.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:32 teaches the opposite: he that is slow to anger is better than the mighty.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 16:13 says kings love those who speak right and delight in righteous lips.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:13 states that righteous lips are the delight of kings and they love him that speaketh right.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Proverbs 16:24: 'Pleasant words are as a _______, sweet to the soul, and health to the bones.'
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:24 uses the metaphor of pleasant words being like a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and health to the bones.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:25, what is the end of the way that seemeth right unto a man?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:25 warns that there is a way that seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death.

medium.title: Proverbs Chapter 16 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Proverbs Chapter 16 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and its consequences. Based on Proverbs 16, what biblical truth would you share about pride and humility?
options: Pride leads to destruction, but humility brings honor
Pride is rewarded by the Lord with blessings
Humility causes one to lose favor with God
Pride is acceptable if kept secret
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to destruction, but humility brings honor
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:18 warns that 'Pride goeth before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall,' and Proverbs 16:31 shows 'The hoary head is a crown of glory, if it be found in the way of righteousness,' highlighting the honor in humility and righteousness.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 16 teach us about trusting God in our plans and decisions?
options: A man's heart deviseth his way, but the LORD directeth his steps
Man's plans are always better than God's
We should rely solely on our own wisdom
God has no interest in our daily decisions
questions.correctAnswer: A man's heart deviseth his way, but the LORD directeth his steps
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:9 clearly states that while humans make plans, it is God who ultimately directs their steps, reminding us to trust His guidance in all our decisions (see also Proverbs 16:1, Proverbs 16:3).

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16, what role does righteousness play in leadership and authority?
options: Righteousness is essential to establish a king's throne
Leaders should be harsh to show power
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness is essential to establish a king's throne
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:12 states 'It is an abomination to kings to commit wickedness: for the throne is established by righteousness,' emphasizing that just leadership is foundational to authority (also Proverbs 16:10, 16:13).

questions.question: A believer is feeling discouraged about small earnings. According to Proverbs 16, what biblical principle can encourage contentment?
options: Better a little with righteousness than great revenues without right
Great wealth is the sign of God's favor
questions.correctAnswer: Better a little with righteousness than great revenues without right
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:8 teaches that having little with righteousness is better than great revenues gained unjustly, encouraging believers to value integrity over wealth (see also Proverbs 16:20, 16:22).

questions.question: How should a believer respond to anger according to Proverbs 16?
options: Be slow to anger and rule your spirit
Express anger quickly to show strength
questions.correctAnswer: Be slow to anger and rule your spirit
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:32 highlights that 'He that is slow to anger is better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his spirit than he that taketh a city,' teaching self-control and patience as virtues (also Proverbs 16:6).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 16 say about the power of words and speech?
options: Pleasant words are sweet to the soul and health to the bones
Words have little effect on others
Speaking harshly is a sign of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Pleasant words are sweet to the soul and health to the bones
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:24 teaches that pleasant words are like honeycomb, sweet and beneficial, encouraging believers to speak graciously (see also Proverbs 16:13, 16:21-23).

questions.question: True or False: According to Proverbs 16, the preparations of a man's heart and the answers of his tongue are ultimately from God.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:1 states that 'The preparations of the heart in man, and the answer of the tongue, is from the LORD,' confirming that God influences our thoughts and speech.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 16 teaches that a violent man leads others into the way that is good and righteous.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:29 warns that 'A violent man enticeth his neighbour, and leadeth him into the way that is not good,' showing that violence leads to evil influence.

questions.question: In Proverbs 16, what is the result of committing your works unto the LORD?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:3 teaches that committing works to the LORD leads to established thoughts and success, encouraging devotion and trust (also Proverbs 16:9).

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16, how does God view the spirits or intentions of men compared to their own self-assessment?
options: The LORD weighs the spirits, though a man sees his ways as clean
God ignores the intentions of men
Men's ways are always evil before God
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD weighs the spirits, though a man sees his ways as clean
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:2 explains that although all ways seem right to a man, the LORD weighs the spirit, indicating divine judgment beyond human perception (see also Proverbs 16:1).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The highway of the upright is to ______ evil: he that keepeth his way preserveth his soul.'
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:17 states that the upright depart from evil, which preserves their souls, teaching moral discipline and integrity.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 16 describe the effect of wise words spoken with a wise heart?
options: They teach the mouth and add learning to lips
They bring shame to the speaker
questions.correctAnswer: They teach the mouth and add learning to lips
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:23 explains that the heart of the wise instructs the mouth and increases learning, highlighting the value of wise communication (also Proverbs 16:21).

questions.question: A believer is facing enemies and conflict. Based on Proverbs 16, what hope can you share about God's intervention?
options: When a man's ways please the LORD, he makes even his enemies to be at peace with him
Enemies will always triumph over the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: When a man's ways please the LORD, he makes even his enemies to be at peace with him
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:7 encourages believers that pleasing God can bring peace even with enemies, emphasizing God's power over relationships.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 16 say about the consequences of sowing strife through words?
options: A froward man soweth strife, and a whisperer separateth chief friends
questions.correctAnswer: A froward man soweth strife, and a whisperer separateth chief friends
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:28 warns that someone who is perverse causes conflict and division, teaching the importance of peace and truthful speech.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16, what is the relationship between mercy, truth, and departing from evil?
options: By mercy and truth iniquity is purged, and by the fear of the LORD men depart from evil
Mercy and truth have no effect on sin
Departing from evil depends only on human effort
Fear of the LORD causes men to embrace evil
questions.correctAnswer: By mercy and truth iniquity is purged, and by the fear of the LORD men depart from evil
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:6 teaches that mercy, truth, and reverence for God lead to cleansing from sin and turning away from evil, encouraging godly living.

hard.title: Proverbs Chapter 16 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Proverbs Chapter 16.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:1, what is the source of both the preparations of the heart and the answer of the tongue?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:1 states that the preparations of the heart in man and the answer of the tongue come from the LORD, emphasizing divine sovereignty over human intentions and speech.

questions.question: Proverbs 16:2 highlights a contrast between man's perspective and God's judgment. What does the LORD weigh?
questions.explanation: The verse contrasts man’s self-righteous view with God’s deeper assessment, stating that the LORD weighs the spirits, indicating divine insight into human inner nature.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 16:3 describe the effect of committing one’s works to the LORD?
questions.explanation: Committing works to the LORD leads to stability and confirmation of one’s plans and thoughts, as indicated in Proverbs 16:3.

questions.question: What theological concept is illustrated in Proverbs 16:4 with God making 'even the wicked for the day of evil'?
questions.explanation: The verse teaches that God’s sovereignty extends even over the wicked, who are part of His providential plan, reflecting a complex view of divine control over all events.

questions.question: Proverbs 16:5 calls proud hearts an abomination to the LORD. What consequence is promised for the proud, even if 'hand join in hand'?
questions.explanation: The verse warns that pride is detestable to God and punishment is certain, regardless of alliances or support.

questions.question: Proverbs 16:6 presents a triad related to departing from evil. Which of the following is NOT part of this triad?
questions.explanation: Mercy, truth, and fear of the LORD are presented as means by which iniquity is purged and men depart from evil; wealth is not mentioned.

questions.question: What is the effect on a man’s enemies when his ways please the LORD, according to Proverbs 16:7?
options: His enemies are at peace with him
questions.correctAnswer: His enemies are at peace with him
questions.explanation: The verse teaches that divine favor leads to peace even with adversaries, indicating God's protective influence.

questions.question: Proverbs 16:8 states that it is better to have what, rather than great revenues without right?
questions.explanation: The verse values moral integrity over material gain obtained unjustly, highlighting the ethical priority in biblical wisdom.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'A man's heart deviseth his way: but the ______ directeth his steps.'
questions.explanation: This verse (Proverbs 16:9) contrasts human planning with divine guidance, showing God’s ultimate control over human actions.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:10, whose lips contain a divine sentence that does not transgress in judgment?
questions.explanation: The verse indicates that the king's words are divinely inspired in matters of judgment, reflecting the ancient Near Eastern concept of royal authority as God’s representative.

questions.question: What is described as the LORD's work in Proverbs 16:11?
questions.explanation: The verse uses the metaphor of just weights and measures as symbols of God's justice and fairness in human affairs.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 16:12 teaches that wickedness is acceptable to kings as long as it benefits their throne.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:12 states that committing wickedness is an abomination to kings because their throne is established by righteousness.

questions.question: What type of lips delight kings, as noted in Proverbs 16:13?
questions.explanation: Kings favor those who speak rightly and justly, as righteousness in speech is portrayed as a virtue that pleases rulers.

questions.question: Proverbs 16:18 contains a famous proverb about pride. What does 'pride' precede, according to this verse?
questions.explanation: This verse teaches the moral principle that pride leads to downfall, a theme echoed throughout Scripture.

questions.question: What is the relationship between the 'hoary head' and righteousness in Proverbs 16:31?
options: The hoary head is a crown of glory if found in the way of righteousness
Righteousness is irrelevant to old age
The hoary head is a burden to the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: The hoary head is a crown of glory if found in the way of righteousness
questions.explanation: This verse honors aged wisdom and righteousness, valuing a righteous life that leads to a glorious reputation in old age.

theological.title: Proverbs Chapter 16 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Proverbs Chapter 16 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:1, what is the origin of the preparations of the heart and the answer of the tongue?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:1 states that the preparations of the heart in man and the answer of the tongue are from the LORD, indicating divine sovereignty over human intentions and speech. This aligns with Jeremiah 10:23, Psalm 33:11, James 1:17, Isaiah 55:8-9, and Philippians 2:13, which affirm God's control and guidance over human plans.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 16:5 say about the proud in heart in relation to the LORD?
options: They are an abomination to the LORD
They are favored by the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They are an abomination to the LORD
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:5 declares that everyone proud in heart is an abomination to the LORD and will not go unpunished. This is consistent with biblical teachings such as James 4:6, 1 Peter 5:5, Isaiah 2:11, Proverbs 8:13, and Luke 18:14, which emphasize God's opposition to pride.

questions.question: What is the result when a man's ways please the LORD, according to Proverbs 16:7?
options: He makes even his enemies to be at peace with him
He gains great wealth and power
questions.correctAnswer: He makes even his enemies to be at peace with him
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:7 teaches that when a man's ways please the LORD, God causes even his enemies to live at peace with him. This reflects God's sovereign peace-making power, as seen in Romans 12:18, Matthew 5:9, Hebrews 12:14, Isaiah 54:17, and 2 Corinthians 5:18.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:9, whose direction ultimately governs a man's steps?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:9 states that although a man plans his way, it is the LORD who directs his steps, emphasizing divine providence. This teaching is supported by Psalm 37:23, Jeremiah 10:23, Isaiah 55:8-9, James 4:13-15, and Proverbs 3:5-6.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 16:12 say about the character required for kings to establish their throne?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:12 teaches that it is an abomination for kings to commit wickedness because the throne is established by righteousness. This principle is echoed in Psalm 72:1-4, 1 Timothy 2:1-2, Ecclesiastes 10:16-17, Isaiah 32:1, and Romans 13:1-4, showing the biblical ideal of godly leadership.

questions.question: What is described as better than great revenues without right in Proverbs 16:8?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:8 states that 'Better is a little with righteousness than great revenues without right,' emphasizing the value of integrity over ill-gotten gain. This is consistent with Psalm 37:16, Matthew 6:19-21, Luke 16:10, Hebrews 13:5, and 1 Timothy 6:6-10, which prioritize godly living over wealth.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:18, what precedes destruction and a fall?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:18 famously states, 'Pride goeth before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall,' teaching about the dangers of arrogance. This truth is affirmed in Isaiah 14:12-15, Luke 1:51-53, James 4:6, 1 Corinthians 10:12, and Galatians 6:7.

questions.question: What blessing does Proverbs 16:20 attribute to one who handles matters wisely and trusts in the LORD?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:20 teaches that he who handles matters wisely will find good, and whoever trusts in the LORD is happy. This aligns with Psalm 1:1-3, Jeremiah 17:7-8, Matthew 7:24-27, Romans 15:13, and Philippians 4:6-7, which link wisdom and trust in God with blessing and joy.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 16:22 describe understanding?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:22 calls understanding a wellspring of life to the possessor, contrasting with folly in fools. This concept is supported by Proverbs 3:13-18, John 6:63, James 1:5, Psalm 119:105, and Colossians 1:9-10, emphasizing understanding’s life-giving nature.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:25, what is deceptive about the way that seems right to a man?
options: Its end is the way of death
It is always accepted by others
questions.correctAnswer: Its end is the way of death
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:25 warns that a way may seem right to a man, but its end leads to death. This caution is echoed in Jeremiah 10:23, Matthew 7:13-14, Romans 3:10-12, Isaiah 55:8-9, and Hebrews 10:26-31, underscoring the danger of relying on human judgment apart from God.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 16:32 say about the value of self-control compared to physical might?
options: He who rules his spirit is better than he who takes a city
Anger is a sign of strength
Physical strength is the highest virtue
questions.correctAnswer: He who rules his spirit is better than he who takes a city
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:32 extols self-control and patience above physical conquest, teaching that ruling one's spirit is superior to capturing a city. This aligns with Galatians 5:22-23, James 1:19-20, 2 Timothy 1:7, Psalm 37:8, and Ecclesiastes 7:8.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 16:11 indicate about just weights and balances?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:11 declares that just weights and balances are the LORD's work, emphasizing divine concern for justice and fairness. This is consistent with Leviticus 19:35-36, Deuteronomy 25:13-16, Micah 6:8, Amos 8:4-6, and Luke 6:38.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 16:14, how should a wise man respond to the wrath of a king?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:14 teaches that although a king's wrath is like messengers of death, a wise man will pacify it. This reflects wisdom in handling authority, as seen in Ecclesiastes 10:4-5, Proverbs 15:1, Romans 12:18, and 1 Peter 2:13-17.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'hoary head' according to Proverbs 16:31?
options: A crown of glory if found in the way of righteousness
A sign of weakness and frailty
questions.correctAnswer: A crown of glory if found in the way of righteousness
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:31 describes the hoary head as a crown of glory when it is found in the way of righteousness, honoring godly old age. This is consistent with Leviticus 19:32, Job 12:12, Psalm 92:12-14, Isaiah 46:4, and 1 Timothy 5:1-2.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 16:24 say about pleasant words?
options: They are like a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and health to the bones
They are often deceptive and harmful
questions.correctAnswer: They are like a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and health to the bones
questions.explanation: Proverbs 16:24 compares pleasant words to honeycomb, emphasizing their sweetness and health-giving effect. This metaphor is supported by Ephesians 4:29, Colossians 4:6, Proverbs 12:25, Psalm 19:10, and Proverbs 15:23.
